headline.translation[0].definitions[0].d: the title of a newspaper report, which is printed in large letters above the report
headline.translation[0].definitions[0].e: a paper carrying the front-page headline: ‘Space Aliens meet with President’
headline.translation[0].note_box[0].head: – Meanings 1 & 3
headline.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: The newspaper's front-page headline read simply 'Prime Minister resigns'.
Celebrity divorces have made big headlines.
Le Monde ran its famous banner headline ' We are all Americans now'.
The story dominated newspaper headlines around the world.
One tabloid headline read 'Doctor of Death'.
The singer was back in the headlines for partying every night.
Madonna's adoption of the child grabbed world headlines.
Crane hit the headlines after she was arrested for the murder of her husband.
News from Iraq continued to dominate the headlines.
The Times carried the headline ‘7.4 Earthquake hits Los Angeles.’
One tabloid paper ran the headline: ‘Disney Theme Park Found On Mars’.
I just read the main headlines.
The next morning’s headlines read: ‘Moors Search for Missing Boys’.
headline.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to appear as the main performer or band in a show
headline.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Beyoncé is headlining at the festival this year.
headline.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to give a headline to an article or story
headline.translation[1].definitions[1].n: Headline is usually passive in this meaning
headline.translation[2].definitions[0].d: in Britain, a figure that shows the general level of inflation, including MORTGAGE payments (=repayments on a loan for buying a house)
headline.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The headline rate of inflation is being pushed towards 4% by higher mortgage costs.
headline.translation[2].definitions[1].d: when a person or company trades or invests on the basis of information they get from the news
